intro: Scleria abortiva, commonly known as the narrow-leaved bulrush, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland environments in southern Africa. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with narrow, linear leaves. The plant produces small, three-lobed flowers that are typically arranged in dense clusters at the ends of its flowering stems. Scleria abortiva thrives in moist soils and is often found in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of water bodies. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems, contributing to soil stabilization and providing habitat for various wildlife species.
